Wale Aliyu, WKYC 12:15 a.m. EDT October 15, 2015 - 1 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
CLEVELAND -- Rooting on our three major teams is the fun part, maintaining them is the expensive part. 
Cuyahoga County Executive Armond Budish introduced legislation this week to cover renovations of the three arenas. 
Cuyahoga County is preparing to finance $60 million worth of repairs to the arenas. The roof over Quicken Loans Arena will soon be replaced, and the Cleveland Indians will get a scoreboard upgrade. FirstEnergy Stadium could also see some renovations. 
The money comes from the county's latest 20-year tax on alcohol and cigarettes, which voters approved in 2014. The controversial legislation passed last year with 56 percent of the vote. 
The county began collecting the taxes in August. - Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay 
It is expected to raise at least $260 million. For the first time, the county will start to distribute some of the earnings with about one-fourth of the expected revenue going towards the upgrades. 
Budish says because they are bonding money, the tax payers will not be paying any additional funds. 
"We are obligated to keep those facilities up," said Budish. "The sin tax was what was determined by the voters to use to pay for those facilities. If the sin tax hadn't passed, we are still obligated under the leases to keep up the buildings." 
READ MORE | Josh McCown practices despite ankle soreness 
The teams want the sin tax money to be split evenly. That will be decided once the legislation goes before a committee. 
Cavaliers owner Dan Gilbert has already fronted money for some renovations, including the new scoreboard and sound system that were installed before the start of last season.
